title: Pitchforks for Paula Dwyer at Tabcorp AGM
text:
Having thoroughly traumatised the nation’s public broadcaster, you’d have hoped he’d slip wordlessly off Tabcorp’s board after eight years. Self-evidently, situational awareness and emotional intelligence are not resources Milne possesses surfeit resources of. Neither have his fellow directors displayed the presence of mind to tap him on the shoulder.

Then there’s Dwyer, whose biography disingenuously introduces her as “chairman and non-executive director of Tabcorp since June 2011.” While Dwyer became chairman of Tabcorp upon the demerger of Echo Entertainment (now Star), when her predecessor John Story switched to chair the casino business, she had actually been a Tabcorp director since August 2005. Er, you don’t get to reset your tenure every time the company flogs a division. That is totally not a thing! Cynically, Tabcorp started presenting directors’ service this way only in 2016, five years after the fact.

After 14 years, not eight, Dwyer wants another two and, ironically, her board’s abysmal succession planning is her very selling point. She’s it! In an industry where directors’ regulatory clearance can take a year or longer, Tabcorp’s leadership cupboard is otherwise bare – though you certainly wouldn’t recognise that manifest reality in the annual report’s fetching Board Skills Matrix, in which the directors, exuding typical acumen dysmorphia, self-assess both their technical skills and experience to be commendably 8 out of 10, except in the non-core disciplines of “gambling industry experience” and “information technology”. And Milne’s people skills?

Money-laundering breaches

Otherwise, wouldn’t institutional shareholders be demanding some accountability for Tabcorp’s 236 breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism finance laws (AUSTRAC fined it $45 million in 2017) and the $200 million it dusted on the disastrous Sun Bets joint venture with News UK?

Or even just adequate oversight of executive management? In a year where the wagering business was again the key drag on group performance (with its full-year earnings falling $26 million short of consensus and 2H earnings down 22 per cent before Tatts synergies thanks to poor execution and cost control), the board granted its managing director Adam Rytenskild 80 per cent of his short term incentives. It used its discretion to pay outgoing CFO Damien Johnson 85 per cent of his, and all of it in cash. And this is after a first strike at last year’s AGM! Does chief executive David Attenborough play old Beth Rowley records on supersonic frequency through the night at board retreats?! You got me wrapped around your little finger…

Dwyer earns $530,350 a year as autopilot ... sorry, chairman, and Milne is paid $208,050. Dwyer attended 24 board and committee meetings in FY19. Milne attended 15.

Sick of deaf ears and empty assurances, major shareholders – including Investors Mutual (just below 5 per cent of the register) and the mighty AustralianSuper (6.6 per cent) are starting to bang their cutlery on the table. Just 16 more sleeps …
description: After 14 years, Dwyer wants another two, and ironically, her board’s abysmal succession planning is her very selling point.
